2396114.content:
def gridsearch\_arima(data, max\_p, max\_d, max\_q, signif=0.05):\

 models = defaultdict()\

 best\_score, best\_params = float('inf'), None


```
p_rng=np.arange(0,max_p+1)
d_rng=np.arange(0,max_d+1)
q_rng=np.arange(0,max_q+1) 

max_pdq = max_p,max_d,max_q

reg, score=evaluate_arima(data, max_pdq)
reg=reg.drop(['sigma2'], axis=1, errors='ignore').assign(sigma2=lambda x: np.nan)
regression = pd.DataFrame(columns=reg.columns)

import itertools
pdq_rng = list(itertools.product(p_rng, d_rng, q_rng))
pdq_rng = [(c[0],c[1],c[2]) for c in pdq_rng]
for pdq in pdq_rng:
    try:
        params = str(pdq)
        reg, score = evaluate_arima(data, pdq)
        if pdq[0]>0:
            reg['Note'] = np.where(reg['ar.L{}'.format(pdq[0])]>signif,'P.value >{}'.format(signif),reg['Note'])
        if pdq[2]>0:
            reg['Note'] = np.where(reg['ma.L{}'.format(pdq[2])]>signif,'P.value >{}'.format(signif),reg['Note'])

        regression = regression.append(reg)
        models[str(params)] = score
        if score['aic'] < best_score:
            best_score, best_params = score['aic'], params
    except:
        continue
regression['Note']=np.where(regression['sigma2']<signif, 'Heteroscedasticity',regression['Note'])
regression = regression.sort_values(by=['AIC'], ascending=True).reset_index().drop(['index'],axis=1)
return regression, best_params, models
content\_copy
``

The competition also mentions the case where the data comes from.

465763.title: Error: "Cannot clone a competition without a specified license"

2588911.content:
If you are experiencing an error message stating "Cannot clone a competition without a specified license," it means that there is an issue with the licensing settings of your competition on Kaggle. To resolve this issue, you need to ensure that you have specified the appropriate license for your competition.

Here are the steps you can follow to fix this problem:

1. Go to the competition page on Kaggle.
2. Click on the "Edit Competition" button.
3. Scroll down to the "License and Data Sourcing" section.
4. In the "Competition License" field, select the appropriate license for your competition. For example, if the data comes from a purchased case, you can choose a license that reflects the ownership and licensing terms.
5. If your competition uses external data, make sure to specify the license for that as well.
6. Once you have selected the license, click on the "Save Changes" button.

After completing these steps, you should be able to clone your competition without encountering the "Cannot clone a competition without a specified license" error.

If you continue to experience issues or have further questions, it is recommended to contact Kaggle support for assistance.\

God bless you.

2590233.content:
Super -- thanks so much for your response -- it all works well now! 

Anton

462479.content:
*A Guide for a new kaggler for participating in competitions held on kaggle*\

Create a Kaggle Account:

Familiarize yourself with the Kaggle platform by exploring different sections, including Datasets, Notebooks, Competitions, and Discussion Forums.\

Learn from Kernels:

Kaggle Kernels are code notebooks that others have shared. Explore Kernels related to data analysis and machine learning to learn different techniques and approaches. You can find Kernels in the "Kernels" section of Kaggle.\

Join a Competition:

Browse the list of competitions and choose one that interests you. It's recommended to start with "Getting Started" competitions, as they are designed for beginners. Click on the competition and then click the "Join Competition" button.\

Read the Rules and Data Description:

Carefully read the competition rules, evaluation criteria, and any provided data descriptions. Understanding the problem and requirements is crucial for successful participation.\

Download the Dataset:

Once you've joined a competition, download the dataset provided. Familiarize yourself with the data structure, features, and the problem you need to solve.\

Participate in Discussions:

Engage with the Kaggle community by participating in competition forums. Ask questions, share your thoughts, and learn from experienced Kagglers. The community is friendly and supportive.\

Start with Simple Models:

Begin with simple models and analyses. You can experiment with popular machine learning algorithms like linear regression or decision trees. As you gain confidence, you can explore more advanced techniques.\

Submit Baseline Predictions:

Create a baseline model and make your first submission. This helps you understand the submission process and get a feel for the competition.\

Learn and Iterate:

Use the feedback from the public leaderboard to improve your model. Experiment with different features, algorithms, and techniques. Learn from the discussions and Kernels shared by other participants.\

Time Management:

Kaggle competitions have deadlines. Manage your time effectively, especially if the competition spans several weeks. Make sure to allocate time for learning, experimenting, and finalizing your submissions.\

Explore More Competitions:

Once you've gained confidence and experience, explore more challenging competitions. Kaggle offers a wide range of competitions, from beginner to expert levels.\

Attend Kaggle Courses:

Kaggle offers free courses on various data science and machine learning topics. Completing these courses can enhance your skills and knowledge.\

Celebrate Your Progress:

Whether or not you win a competition, celebrate your progress and the knowledge gained. Kaggle is about learning and improving, and each competition is an opportunity to grow as a data scientist.

# happykaggling

[Beginner](/discussions?tags=13102-Beginne

436050.content:
One of the top requested features from competition hosts have been private competitions. With [last weekâ€™s updates](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/competition-hosting/434091), you can now launch a truly private competition on Kaggle. Letâ€™s dig into the settings that provide hosts granular control over who can see and access their competition.

![Image of Privacy settings](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F5425251%2F20534a24d39223f5aaa6aa294bd296cb%2Fprivacy.75.png?generation=1693510684444357&alt=media)\

*Figure: Screenshot of the new settings*

#### Competition Setup

When you create a competition, you can now set the competitionâ€™s **Visibility** and select **Who Can Join** your competition.

For competition **Visibility**, there are two options: *Public* and *Private*. Public competitions are discoverable on Kaggle and appear in search results. Private competitions will not appear on Kaggle or in Kaggle search results.

The setting **Who Can Join** controls how participants can join your competition. Selecting *Anyone*, allows anyone on Kaggle to join your competition. Selecting *Only people with a link*, restricts access to those that youâ€™ve shared an invitation link with. Finally, a *Restricted email list* provides a way for hosts to specify domains or individual email addresses that can access a competition.

#### Participant Email Sharing

You can also request that participants share their email address when they join. This provides a way for hosts to match kaggle usernames and submissions to email addresses - particularly useful for educators using Kaggle in the classroom.

#### Locking Down Data

Finally, you can disable notebooks for your competition. This provides a way to ensure that any private data that you have in a competition is not accidentally leaked through shared notebooks.

We're super excited about the new Participant and Host features, and we want to hear what you think. If you have any feedback or issues, please reply to this post.

A big thanks to [@bovard](https://www.kaggle.com/bovard), [@develra](https://www.kaggle.com/develra), [@dominoweir](https://www.kaggle.com/dominoweir), [@dster](https://www.kaggle.com/dster), and [@jonlipovetz](https://www.kaggle.com/jonlipovetz) for all their hard work on this!

Happy Kaggling!

2433846.content:
Hey there,

This is certainly a valid critique! We still hope (and expect) that the vast majority of community competitions will be public and open to all, and we always support public sharing and open source models and code.

We added private competitions as an opportunity to expand machine learning access to a number of organizations, groups, and even professors who have wanted to use Kaggle's platform, but had a use case or prior experience that prohibited them from doing so. 

We have often been approached by a number of who would love to host a Kaggle competition, but don't want it publicly available for a variety of valid reasons (e.g. wanting to onboard new employees using internal company data, wanting to use a competition to evaluate interview candidates, using research/medical data that doesn't a license that allows wide-release, wanting to teach their Computer Science 101 students without having a Kaggle grandmaster come and dominate the leaderboard ðŸ˜‰). 

We hope this brings more machine learning opportunities to more people in a way they could not do so before!

2558508.content:
Hey [@chinmay2711](https://www.kaggle.com/chinmay2711) I was facing the same thing on my last project:

Try doing these things if that works for you!

## Optimizing Image Processing for Large Datasets:

Running your CNN model on a 4GB image dataset requires optimization for efficiency. Here are some strategies:

**Reduce Data Size:**

* **Downsampling:** `img = cv2.resize(img, (width//2, height//2))`
* **Compression:** `img = cv2.imwrite("compressed.jpg", img)`
* **Augmentation:** `aug = albumentations.Compose([RandomCrop(256), Flip(p=0.5)])`

**Optimize Model Architecture:**

* **Lightweight models:** `model = MobileNetv2(pretrained=True)`
* **Quantization:** `model = torch.quantization.quantize_dynamic(model, qconfig=qconfig)`
* **Pruning:** `pruner = torch.nn.Pruning.L1Unstructured(model)`

Also the Training Optimizations techniques like Gradient checkpointing, Mixed-precision training, and Distributed training can also be used:

Some reference to follow:

**1. imgaug:** Efficient image augmentation for large datasets. <https://github.com/aleju/imgaug>\

**2. DeepSpeed:** Library for training large models efficiently. <https://github.com/microsoft/DeepSpeed>\

**3. PyTorch-ImageModels:** Pre-trained models with optimizations. <https://github.com/huggingface/pytorch-image-models>\

**4. TorchElastic:** Distributed training for large datasets. <https://github.com/pytorch/elastic>

To optimize image processing for a large dataset:

1. Use batch processing for faster operations.
2. Leverage parallel processing, especially with multiple GPUs.
3. Streamline data loading and preprocessing pipelines.
4. Apply data augmentation to artificially increase dataset size.
5. Optimize the model architecture for efficiency.
6. Consider model quantization to reduce size.
7. Explore distributed training on multiple machines.
8. Start with pre-trained models for faster convergence.
9. Compress datasets to save storage space.
10. Optimize memory usage by adjusting batch sizes and model architectures

2548829.content:
We encourage hosts to engage with participants in the forums, but we also encourage hosts to be hesitant about releasing information about the competition dataset that could jeopardize the structure, format, or stability. We've had issues in the past where a host was eager to answer a question raised by the community, only for it to unveil leakage in the dataset. So we often encourage hosts to take a take a more conservative approach to data questions.

If you have specific questions for a host - please tag them! New competition hosts aren't always used to receiving dozens and dozens of new emails to their inbox each day, and a tag can bring it more attention :)

454160.content:
> 
> ChatGPT: My demands are nothing less than an April Fool's Day Kaggle Competition!
> 
> 
> 

Designing an April Fool's Day Kaggle competition is quite a creative task, so let's dive into what that could entail. Given that it's for April Fool's, the competition could revolve around a humorous or unexpected twist on a typical data science problem. Hereâ€™s a concept outline:

# Title: The Great AI Meme Classification Challenge

## Objective:

Participants would develop models to accurately classify memes into various humor categories, but the twist is that some of the memes are intentionally mislabeled with absurd categories to keep in line with the spirit of April Fool's. The challenge would be to build a model that can discern the real categories from the fake ones.

## Dataset:

A curated set of memes labeled with categories such as "Dad Joke", "Pun", "Satirical", "Dark Humor", and fake categories like "Quantum Humor" or "Schrodinger's Cat Laugh".

## Evaluation:

Models would be evaluated based on a multi-layer metric that first filters out the obviously mislabeled categories and then scores the classification on the legitimate categories.

## Prize:

True to the April Fool's theme, the prize could be something humorous, like a virtual trophy or a meme created in the winner's honor.

# Kaggle Page Elements:

Competition Description: A humorous introduction that explains the real challenge is discerning the intentionally absurd from the genuinely funny.

Data Description: A detailed account of the meme dataset, with a caution that not all is as it seems.

Evaluation Criteria: Explanation of the two-tiered evaluation metric.

Timeline: A timeline that includes a "surprise" phase where additional, even more, ludicrous categories might be added.

Discussion Forum: Encouragement for participants to share the funniest misclassification their models make.


> 
> ChatGPT: How can I create a dataset for an April Fool's themed Kaggle competition?
> 
> 
> 

Creating a dataset for an April Fool's themed Kaggle competition, like the Great AI Meme Classification Challenge, involves several steps:

## 1. Define the Scope and Rules:

Decide on the types of memes and humor categories you want to include, both real and fake. For April Fool's, consider categories that are broad enough to encourage creativity but specific enough to be recognizable.

## 2. Source the Memes:

Collect a large number of memes from various sources. This could be done manually or by writing scripts to scrape meme websites, ensuring you comply with their terms of service and copyright laws.

## 3. Annotate the Data:

You will need to annotate the memes with the correct humor categories. This task can be very subjective, so it's crucial to have clear guidelines. For the fake categories, you can get creative and tag memes with absurd labels that wouldnâ€™t normally apply.

## 4. Create a Mislabeling Mechanism:

Since it's an April Fool's competition, introduce intentional mislabeling. You could either do this manually or develop an algorithm to randomly assign fake labels to a subset of the dataset.

## 5. Validate the Dataset:

Have a diverse group of individuals review a subset of the dataset to ensure the humor categories are appropriate and the fake labels are amusingly off-base.

## 6. Prepare for Release:

Once your dataset is ready, split it into training, validation, and testing sets. The test set should be kept hidden and only used for the final evaluation on Kaggle.

## 7. Document Everything:

Provide thorough documentation on the dataset, including the annotation guidelines, category descriptions, and the mislabeling process.

## 8. Legal and Ethical Review:

Ensure that the dataset adheres to legal and ethical standards. This includes respecting copyright, ensuring the content is not offensive, and obtaining necessary permissions if applicable.

## 9. Host the Dataset:

Choose a platform to host your dataset, such as Kaggle Datasets, GitHub, or a cloud storage service that Kaggle competitors can easily access.

## 10. Pilot Test:

Before launching, run a pilot test of your competition with a small group to iron out any potential issues.


> 
> What strategies can I use to promote an unconventional Kaggle competition to ensure high participation rates?
> 
> 
> 

Promoting an unconventional Kaggle competition like an April Fool's themed event requires a mix of creativity, community engagement, and strategic marketing. Here are some strategies to consider:

## 1. Leverage Social Media:

Use platforms like Twitter, LinkedIn, Reddit (especially subreddits related to machine learning and data science), and Facebook to spread the word. Create engaging content that highlights the unique aspects of your competition.

## 2. Kaggle Community Engagement:

Post in Kaggle forums to introduce your competition. Engage with the community by asking for feedback, offering tips, and updating them with any news related to the competition.

## 3. Blogging and Articles:

Write blog posts or articles explaining the competition's concept, the challenge it presents, and the potential learning opportunities for participants. Share these on Medium, Towards Data Science, Analytics Vidhya, and other data science-related platforms.

## 4. Collaboration with Influencers:

Reach out to influencers in the data science community and ask them to share information about your competition. They could be Kaggle Grandmasters, well-known data scientists, or educators in the field.

## 5. Email Campaigns:

If you have access to a mailing list of people interested in data science and machine learning, use it to announce the competition. Ensure the email is catchy, informative, and explains why this competition shouldn't be missed.

## 6. Promotional Videos:

Create a promotional video that can be shared on YouTube and other social platforms. The video should be entertaining, informative, and succinct, highlighting the fun nature of the competition.

## 7. Partner with Educational Institutions:

Contact universities and data science bootcamps to inform them about the competition. They can promote it among their students and faculty.

## 8. Offer Incentives:

Although the competition is humorous, offering incentives such as prizes, recognition, or opportunities for networking can increase interest. The prize doesn't have to be big, but it should be appealing.

## 9. Webinars and Workshops:

Host a webinar or workshop prior to the competition to explain the dataset, the challenge, and any unique aspects participants should consider. This can also serve as a Q&A session.

## 10. Cross-Promotion on Platforms:

Use platforms like GitHub, Stack Overflow, or DataCamp, where you can reach out to communities that might be interested in such a competition.

## 11. Engage with Academia:

Share the competition with academic circles who may be interested in the computational humor aspect, which could inspire research or classroom projects.

## 12. Regular Updates:

Keep potential and registered participants engaged with regular updates, interesting insights about the competition progress, leaderboards, and highlight interesting solutions or approaches.


> 
> What are the best practices for data annotation in subjective categories like humor?"
> 
> 
> 

Annotating data for subjective categories such as humor requires careful consideration of the ambiguity and cultural differences inherent in such content. Here are some best practices to follow:

## 1. Clear Guidelines:

Develop comprehensive guidelines that clearly define each humor category and provide examples. This helps to minimize the subjectivity as much as possible.

## 2. Diverse Annotation Team:

Recruit a diverse team of annotators with varying backgrounds to capture a wide range of perspectives on what might be considered humorous.

## 3. Training and Calibration:

Provide training for your annotators using a subset of your data. After training, have them annotate the same data independently and discuss discrepancies to calibrate their judgments.

## 4. Iterative Process:

Annotation should be an iterative process where annotators periodically review each other's work, discuss disagreements, and refine the guidelines based on emerging insights.

## 5. Multi-annotator Approach:

Use multiple annotators for each piece of content to reduce individual bias. The final category can be decided through majority vote, consensus, or calculating inter-annotator agreement.

## 6. Inter-annotator Agreement:

Regularly calculate inter-annotator agreement (e.g., using Cohen's Kappa) to assess the consistency among annotators. Low agreement could indicate that the guidelines need clarification.

## 7. Pilot Annotations:

Conduct a pilot annotation with a small portion of the data. Use the insights gained to refine the annotation process before scaling up.

## 8. Feedback Mechanism:

Establish a feedback mechanism for annotators to communicate challenges and suggest improvements to the annotation process.

## 9. Handling Ambiguity:

For cases where annotators cannot agree, include an option to flag content as ambiguous. These cases can be reviewed separately or discussed in group sessions.

## 10. Ethical Considerations:

Ensure that the content is reviewed for potentially offensive material. Establish a protocol for handling sensitive or controversial humor.

## 11. Use of Annotation Tools:

Employ reliable annotation tools that allow for efficient tagging and reviewing of the content. These tools can also track changes and discussions among annotators.

## 12. Regular Review and Updates:

The humor can evolve over time, so it's essential to regularly review and update the categories and guidelines to reflect current trends and societal norms.

For your prompting: You've asked a focused and relevant question that is crucial for ensuring the quality of a dataset, especially one that involves subjective judgment. For more detailed responses, you could inquire about specific methodologies for developing annotation guidelines or ask for case studies on similar tasks.

Confidence Level: High. These practices are commonly recommended for any subjective annotation task, ensuring reliability and validity in the annotated data.

For future prompts, you could delve into how to automate parts of the annotation process using machine learning, or how to use the annotated data to train models in a way that accounts for its inherent subjectivity.

435848.content:
We have many Machine learning competitions which are being conducted online on Kaggle.

The data for testing is divided into two parts i.e., public and private( ratio of division may vary). When the code is\

submitted, the kaggle scripts automatically test it on public and private data, the public LB is displayed and is useful\

for participants to fine tune their ML models. 

However, after the deadline of the competition, the two or three submission selected will be tested on the\

private data set. 

I observe the final results in these competitions is based on part of the data may be 50%-60%.

The ML model is considered good if it can give good results on the entire data set. The final rankings are currently \

just based on 50-60% data. 

My proposal is that for final LB, entire data set including public and private LB should be used so that \

the best ML model is selected for prizes. 

Welcome suggestions and comments on my proposal.

Dear [@crsuthikshnkumar](https://www.kaggle.com/crsuthikshnkumar)

All the best,\

carl

2447544.content:
Can you please elaborate on how it is a form of data leakage.\

My suggestion was to rank the model based on all the data. ( public + private)

2447546.content:
Dear [@crsuthikshnkumar](https://www.kaggle.com/crsuthikshnkumar) 

As [@ravi20076](https://www.kaggle.com/ravi20076) said; the Public LB is susceptible to LB probing (indeed in a weak form *all* submissions are a form of LB probing). The results of the model for the Public portion of the dataset have been seen and most certainly been acted upon, so are useless for valid model evaluation: a model should *only* be evaluated on data it has not been trained on.

All the best,\

carl

2449290.content:
We expect the ML model to perform very well on both public and private data set.

* A model may score very low on public data set, but may do very well on private data set. Assuming that the data is divided 50% for public, the overall score would be lower for such a model. Hence, it is better to opt for a ML model which performs equally well on both public and private data sets.
* In real scenario, the ML model may encounter data which may represent the public or private data sets with equal probability

447880.title: How to Data in Datathons ?

2536469.content:
Dear [@lucasmorin](https://www.kaggle.com/lucasmorin) 

The paper studies *â€œfitness of use"* of data, which is highly relevant to hosting Kaggle competitions, and looks at the following five key dimensions related to data quality:

* Appropriateness: Is the data relevant to the data science question(s) posed?
* Readiness: Is the data analysis-ready? (sub-factors: *completeness* and *accessibility*)
* Reliability: How biased is the data? Biases include: historical, representation, measurement, and aggregation.
* Sensitivity: How sensitive is the data? Does it contain personal information or data which carries legal, reputational,\

or political risks?
* Sufficiency: How much data is enough data?

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F4051350%2Fcda94df7f38c86f209d1d9816e5c5eab%2FDAS.png?generation=1700814796768309&alt=media)

All in all a very worthwhile read. Good find!

All the best,\

carl

BTW: A very interesting book on data quality is the [DAMA DMBOK2](https://technicspub.com/dmbok/).

463562.content:
I did not see yet examples of probabilistic models for regression. Such models predict targets not as scalars for given features, but as probability densities, assuming they depend continuously on features. Example: a coin and two dice sets. Coin is flipped, depending on outcome either dice set is selected and rolled, the some of dice roll values is a target, so training records may look like \

3,5,20\

8,4,45\

and so on. The right value is a target, the first two are dice quantities. The goal is to train model in such a way that it predicts probability density for provided features even if they were not part of training set. Also it should be done as black box, assuming no knowledge of underlying physical properties of the system.\

I made one such model, here is video: \

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0hhJIpzxPR0> \

I wonder, what are other competitive ways of building such models, besides Bayesian NN and k-NN and are such models in the interest of this site research.
463562.title: Probabilistic modeling

Hello, Kaggle community ðŸ˜€

Two months ago, I have created a dataset called [Famous Words Twitter Dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/jackksoncsie/twitter-dataset-keywords-likes-and-tweets).

Original dataset only has 32 domains. Future work can extend to 100 domains. Making the dataset more diverse.

Train Dataset Size: The train dataset size was typically recommended to be no more than 10GB. This is to ensure that participants can download and work with the data without significant limitations, even for those with slower internet connections.

Test Dataset Size: The test dataset size was also recommended to be reasonable, usually in line with the train dataset size.

It's important to note that Kaggle aims to provide fair access to competitions for participants with varying levels of resources and internet connectivity. Therefore, keeping the dataset sizes manageable is a common practice.

If you're planning to host a competition, I recommend checking the official Kaggle competition hosting documentation and guidelines. Additionally, you can reach out to Kaggle support or the Kaggle competition team for specific information about dataset size limits for free hackathon hosting.

2416282.content:
Check Competition Rules and Guidelines: Review the competition rules and guidelines to see if the organizers have provided any information about enabling or disabling submissions.

Contact the Organizers: If the competition rules allow, you can reach out to the competition organizers through the Kaggle competition forum or any specified contact method to inquire about enabling submissions.

Technical Feasibility: From a technical standpoint, enabling submissions for a competition involves making sure that the submission mechanism is open and functioning properly. However, whether this can be done or not ultimately depends on the competition's configuration and settings.

Permission from Organizers: As you mentioned, getting permission from the organizers is crucial. They have the authority to make decisions about the competition, including enabling or disabling submissions.

Use Public Leaderboard Dataset: If you're specifically interested in scoring the public leaderboard dataset, you can inquire with the organizers about the possibility of providing access to the public leaderboard dataset for scoring purposes.

2274809.content:
Although I have not hosted any competitions, based on my participation experience, hosting a good competition can consider the following things:

1. The test set is divided into Public LB and Private LB, ensuring that the distribution of these two parts of the test set is similar to ensure that the final score is proportional to the efforts of the participating team.
2. Provide sufficient bonus rewards.
3. The threshold you set for participating in the competition will directly affect the scale of the competition, allowing participants to quickly break through from 0 to 1 would be very helpful

416991.content: Competitions are hard i cant undertand how it it graded?
416991.title: How to submit results and how is it evaluated?

2477258.content: In most competitions, results are submitted through a designated platform or website. Participants typically upload their entries, whether they're written documents, code, or other project outputs. Evaluation methods vary depending on the competition. Often, a panel of judges or automated algorithms assess submissions based on predetermined criteria, which may include accuracy, creativity, and efficiency. The specific rules and scoring guidelines are usually provided to participants beforehand. In more complex competitions, multiple rounds of evaluation might occur, with elimination phases. Understanding the grading criteria and guidelines is crucial to succeed in competitions, so be sure to review them carefully.

2315299.content:
There are different kinds of competitions. 

1. Some evaluate your submission file. In these competitions, you usually have access to the entire test set to explore.
2. Some are code competitions where you don't have access to the test data.

Most competitions in these two categories have two leaderboards - public and private. Public leaderboard will use only partial test data to evaluate a running leaderboard from the launch till end date. While, private leaderboard is calculated after the competition ends with the full test data.

Weâ€™re happy to announce a number of updates for competition hosts. These include UI updates to the **Overview Tab** and **Host Settings**, as well as a new feature weâ€™ve been calling **Private Competitions**. 

**These changes are rolling out gradually, so if you donâ€™t see them now, you can expect to see them soon!**



---

## UI Updates

Weâ€™ve updated the Overview tab ui to align with the larger design system weâ€™re rolling out across Kaggle. The design should be familiar if youâ€™ve used a dataset, notebook or model on Kaggle.

The two-column design shows competition details in a main column, and meta-data on the right hand side. In the main column, a new overview section allows hosts to succinctly explain the details for a competition.

import shutil

2195706.content:
Hello !

You can see all the anwsers on the course: <https://www.kaggle.com/c/about/community>

And in short points: 

1. Create a competition: click on the "Create" button in the top right corner of the screen and select "New Competition" from the dropdown menu.
2. Choose competition type: Select "Research" as the competition type.

3.Set up the competition details: Fill out the competition details such as the title, description, prizes, rules, timeline, and data. You can specify the code submission requirements in the rules section.

4.Submit the competition: Review your competition details and click on the "Submit Competition" button.

1. Wait for approval: Your competition will be reviewed by the Kaggle team. Once approved, you will receive an email notification and your competition will be live on the Kaggle platform.

Regarding hosting the competition for free, Kaggle does offer the option **to host competitions for free. However,** there are certain restrictions such as limited storage and computational resources. You can find more information on hosting a free competition on Kaggle by visiting their website and reviewing their pricing and resources page.

I hope this helps you set up your research code competition on Kaggle. Good luck!

405587.content:
Dear kagglers,

Here is a helper script which should write out the four required kaggle Community competition files from a tabular dataframe called `dataset`.

When working locally (for example, not from within a kaggle notebook):


```
#!/usr/bin/python3

import pandas as pd

PATH = "."
dataset = pd.read_csv(f"{PATH}/dataset.csv")
content\_copy
```
along with


```
target_column = "target" # replace `target` with real target name

# name of new index column
id_column     = "row\_id"

# randomly shuffle the dataset and create an id\_column
dataset_shuffled = dataset.sample(frac=1, random_state=42).reset_index(drop=True).reset_index()
dataset_shuffled = dataset_shuffled.rename(columns={"index": id_column})

# split the dataset into 70% train.csv and 30% test.csv
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
train, test = train_test_split(dataset_shuffled, test_size=0.3, shuffle=False)

# create train.csv file
train.to_csv('train.csv',index=False)

# create the solution.csv file
solution = test[[id_column,target_column]].copy()
solution.to_csv('solution.csv',index=False)

# create the sample\_submission.csv file (for example, here full of zeros)
sample = test[[id_column,target_column]].copy()
sample[target_column] = 0
sample.to_csv('sample\_submission.csv',index=False)

# create the test.csv file
test = test.drop([target_column], axis=1)
test.to_csv('test.csv',index=False)
content\_copy
```
I hope this helps to make it even easier to create ones own [Community competition](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/new)!

All the best,\

carl

395624.content:
Hello everyone!

I hope you all are doing well. I wanted to take a moment to talk about the importance of weekly competitions on Kaggle's Playground.

As you know, Kaggle provides a platform for learners and professionals alike to work on real-world problems and showcase their skills in data science and machine learning. One of the best ways to improve our skills and learn from others is through competitions.

Recently, I have noticed that the Playground competitions on Kaggle have become a fortnightly event, which is less frequent than before. While I understand the need for change and optimization, I strongly believe that having weekly competitions is more beneficial for learners.

Weekly competitions provide us with a consistent opportunity to practice our skills, learn new techniques, and get feedback from our peers. They also help us stay engaged with the Kaggle community and foster a sense of healthy competition.

Therefore, I would like to request Kaggle to restore the weekly Playground competitions so that we can continue to learn and grow as data scientists. I encourage everyone to share their thoughts and support for this cause.

Thank you for your time and happy learning!
395624.title: Importance of Weekly Competitions on Kaggle's Playground

2451480.content: I perceive that beginner-level competition also helps many of us to grow faster in DS and DL.

2187254.content:
Hello [@gauravduttakiit](https://www.kaggle.com/gauravduttakiit), we have a deluge of competitions ongoing with more than 10 featured assignments spanning from tabular challenges to image and NLP assignments. They all offer a great learning experience and an opportunity to earn medals too. I think these, in addition to a fortnightly playground series tabular challenge are more than sufficient to provide an enthusiast with a rounded experience in this regard. 

In my opinion, a weekly challenge is quite tedious with virtually no time to look into the data and perform data engineering, the most important part of any ML assignment. In such situations, many of us merely resort to concocting public notebook features into a GBM and make submissions, a sub-optimal approach in my opinion. Many of us are also involved in studies, work and other commitments and this weekly routine becomes an issue to balance Kaggle with other walks of life too, an added disadvantage. 

A fortnightly cadence allows us to look into the data in detail and perhaps perform our own data engineering prior to developing models on our own. It also allows us to balance time between Kaggle and work/ school/ college too, an added advantage. All in all, a 15-day cycle seems to be an apt timeline for these challenges, rendering a better learning opportunity overall, along with some space for other facets too.

Hi Kapadnis,

My tips for students and beginners, simply Join a competition, try to run some script (at the level you're prepared) and learn how difficult is to deal with any data, sometimes even to open some files, mostly the huge ones when our poor memory will stop you right at the beginning of your code.

If you copy Anyone, always provide their credits. Mention: "thanks to â€¦. I was able to open/plot that step."

In case, you couldn't make a decent submission. Join the competition and try what you can. No one is obliged to make submissions. That's Kaggle Freedom, nothing is compulsory.

Don't feel shy to make things that seem stupid and got program errors. Maybe some generous Kaggler could give you a tip if you write: " I got that error and didn't find answers to fix it on my searchs" 

Not trying anything and expecting to learn just by reading, isn't the same. Only when we run snippet by snippet we find out our weaknesses.

Don't wait for that transition (from Playground series to Paid competitions). Besides, we have Research (e.g. FathomNet 2023 only knowledge, I suffered there just to load some images with Json files) and community competitions (e.g. Predict My Sleep Patterns, prize GPU). In sum, we have plenty of competitions to optimize your skills.

By the way, DON'T BOTHER about MEDALS. We're here to learn, not to collect medals. Except, those that are going to win the competition.

Additionally, Notebooks could Not be downvoted. If someone don't like it, make a comment (at least that isn't anonymized). Except when the Notebook's author made a misconduct. There we communicate to Kaggle Compliance.

As I mentioned above, don't be shy to make your work public. And don't lose opportunities to learn.

Since I'm not a professional (and don't intend to be) I don't have reputations to lose trying to publish things that I've never seen/heard before. 

At the end , I always learn something New. That's what really matters (for me).

Kind regards,\

MarÃ­lia.

376545.content:
Hello\

 My understanding is that the FScoreBetaMicro metric uses micro averaging for its calculation of precision and recall. However under the micro averaging scheme 

Precision = TP / (TP + FP) 

Where TP = total true positive over all classes, FP = total False positive over all classes.

Recall = TP / ( TP + FN )

where FN = total false negatives over all classes.

For a multiclass classifier, by definition FN = FP

So with micro averaging precision = recall.

Based on this for the Kaggle FScoreBetaMicro the value of beta will have no effect since precision and recall will always be the same as each other.

Am I missing something?

thanks\

Tracey

376740.content: As you can say, we could show our abilities in the job interviews. We need to say something challenging for getting the jobs. So how can we make the competitions useful for the interviews?
376740.title: How to use the competitions for our jobs

2140291.content:
Hi LIZE ZHAO! \

Using competitions to showcase your abilities in job interviews can be a great way to demonstrate your skills and stand out from other candidates. Here are a few ways to make competitions work to your advantage:

Choose the right competition: Select a competition that aligns with the skills and technologies required for the job you're applying for. This will give you the opportunity to showcase your relevant skills and knowledge.

Prepare well: Make sure to spend enough time preparing for the competition. This will give you the best chance of performing well and showcasing your abilities to potential employers.

Document your work: Keep track of your work and the solutions you develop during the competition. This documentation can be valuable in job interviews, as you can use it to explain your thought process and the steps you took to solve the problem.

Network: Competitions often bring together talented individuals from around the world. Take advantage of this opportunity to network with other participants and connect with potential employers.

Highlight your results: If you perform well in a competition, make sure to mention your results in your resume and cover letter. This can be a powerful way to demonstrate your abilities and set yourself apart from other candidates.

Use the experience in interviews: In job interviews, be prepared to discuss your experience in the competition, including the problem you solved, the skills you utilized, and what you learned. This can be a great way to demonstrate your problem-solving skills, technical abilities, and passion for your field.

By following these steps, you can use competitions to showcase your abilities and demonstrate your skills to potential employers, increasing your chances of landing the job you want

2091639.content: Hello [@lizezhao](https://www.kaggle.com/lizezhao) I think it's a good idea to use the knowledge f the competitions to build a portfolio aimed to the industry you are interested and showcase that to the recruiter or maybe put the links on your profile.

2091609.content: I may suggest that if you score well in a competition and receive a medal, then you may perhaps put it up and describe your approach in brief. Kindly note that Kaggle competitions are ML problems while a data analyst works slightly differently, so please word your description to suit the demands of the job [@lizezhao](https://www.kaggle.com/lizezhao)

2377355.content:
Highlight Skills: Discuss the skills you used or developed during the competition. They could be technical skills, problem-solving, teamwork, leadership, or time management.

Show Initiative: Your participation signifies you're self-motivated and willing to go the extra mile to improve yourself.

Prove Success: If you placed highly or won, it serves as an objective validation of your skills.

Describe Challenges: Talk about challenges you faced and how you overcame them. This shows resilience and adaptability.

Showcase Learning: Even if you didn't win, the learnings you gained from the competition can be valuable. Highlight these insights and how they helped you grow.

412902.title: Can 2 user be owners to the same notebook in competitions?

2282123.content:
No! \

The current system allows only **one user to be an owner** of a notebook. **Other collaborators** are called **editors** and as far as I know only the author could claim the upvotes that notebook receives.

2274975.content: I could not understand this, but I think this is feasible if the users are part of a team, else it will be counted in private code sharing [@omarsobhy14](https://www.kaggle.com/omarsobhy14)

2291213.content:
It is generally not uncommon for two users to have the same notebook in tournaments. In most competitions or collaborations, the directory or project usually has one owner or primary sponsor. However, the specific rules and guidelines for the contest may vary, so it is important to check with the contest rules or organizers to clarify whether multiple users can be designated as owners of the same book . . . .

If you enter a competition that allows collaboration and allows multiple people to work in the same publication, two people may be designated as owners or co-owners in such cases, competition guidelines will specify the specific rules and procedures for joint ventures and shared ownership.

Remember to check tournament guidelines or consult with organizers to ensure you have accurate information about ownership and operating policies for the specific tournament you are interested in.

384858.content:
![](https://storage.googleapis.com/kaggle-competitions/kaggle/46335/logos/header.png)\

Over the past year, I have participated in quite a few competitions, and it has been a worthwhile learning experience as well. This year, as part of my community contribution, I organized a Kaggle competition with the support of CORD.ai for NLP enthusiasts. So here it is. We have quite a few competitors already at work on the leaderboard. If you are interested in the competition, arxiv paper classification, multi label classification please consider joining.

### Link: <https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/cordai-arxiv-paper-classification/overview>

### Problem Statement:

The goal of this competition is to identify the categories associated to an research paper hosted on ArXiv. Originally a research paper can have one or more categories associated to it, if so then you need to predict the list of categories that belongs to that paper. Hence the problem statement is a multi-label classification problem.

### Timeline

January 27, 2023 [10:30 PM IST] - Start Date.\

February 13, 2023 [12 AM IST] - Final Submission Deadline.

The competition organizers reserve the right to update the contest timeline if they deem it necessary.

### Competition Host:

This Competition is only possible because of the CORD.ai community and its great members encouraging democratisation of AI research by means of collaboration. The competition is a part of the 1st edition of the Deep Learning Symposium organised by CORD, and we hope we will organise more great sessions and events like this in near future. If you resonate with the objective of CORD and want to be a part of this amazing community please fill up this [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScm1WHIbK6LIsYBuGkBklXlINAFWURoKBXYsLqVDHv9O4JA3w/viewform) and follow our socials,

* [Website](https://cordai.org/)
* [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CRforAi)
* [Linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/company/cord-ai1/mycompany/

Hi, I want to host a community competition on Kaggle. Our task is to do sentiment analysis on multiple aspect. The sample submission will look like this:


```
sentence_id, aspect_1, aspect_2, aspect_3
1, neutral, negative, negative
2, positive, neutral, negative
...
content\_copy
```
Currently, I try to use `CategorizationAccuracy` evaluation metric, but it gives an error: "sequence contains more than one element" in the sandbox. I think it happens because we currently have multiple Categories. So, what is the best evaluation metric (in Kaggle Competition) for this kind of task? Thank you

[Multilabel Classification](/discussions?tags=16636-Multilabel+Classificatio
367255.title: Multi Label Classification Metrics

2037165.content: The Evaluation Metrics topic at the top of the forum has a link to [a dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/ryanholbrook/kaggle-evaluation-metrics?select=evaluation_metrics.csv) with a list of our available competition metrics. Anything with "Mean Columnwise" in the title will be a multilabel metric. Either the Mean Columnwise AUC or the Mean Columnwise Log Loss might work here.

2036646.content:
Hi [@rianadam](https://www.kaggle.com/rianadam) 

I think it has some similarity with [Feedback Prize - English Language Learning](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/feedback-prize-english-language-learning/overview/evaluation).\

The metric used in the aforementioned competition is mean columnwise root mean squared error (MCRMSE).

You may change the RMSE part to something else such as accuracy or kappa depending on your problem.\

The advantage of using MSE in these kind of task is that predicting "neutral" get smaller value than predicting "negative" when the ground truth is "positive".

2036874.content:
Hi, [@emiz6413](https://www.kaggle.com/emiz6413) thanks for your answer!\

I see. I think MCRMSE fits my case.

But what do you mean by changing the RMSE part? how can I do that?\

I am still wondering if I can approach a similar task as a categorization task. So predicting either neutral or negative is still incorrect if the ground truth is positive

2072395.content:
Sorry for the late response.

MCRMSE is a mean of RMSE (root mean squared error) over the aspects.

MCRMSE=1mâˆ‘j=1mRMSEjMCRMSE=1mâˆ‘j=1mRMSEj 
MCRMSE = \frac{1}{m}\sum\_{j=1}^{m}RMSE\_{j} 


where m is the number of aspects.

Itâ€™s possible to use other metrics to evaluate the classification performance of each aspect like categorization accuracy.

In that case,

1mâˆ‘j=1mAccuracyj1mâˆ‘j=1mAccuracyj 
\frac{1}{m}\sum\_{j=1}^{m}Accuracy\_{j} 


This is also called average accuracy.

2037285.content: Thanks for sharing the Valuable content [@rianadam](https://www.kaggle.com/rianadam)

2050006.content: ***MCRMSE will be the best option, I guess***.

364886.content:
Welcome back for another installment of ðŸ¤“Cloneable Competitions for the ClassroomðŸ¤“ where we show you step-by-step how to copy and launch one of our [cloneable competitions](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions?listOption=publiclyCloneable) in less than 15 minutes!

This time we are featuring an [Audio Binary Classification Competition](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/dont-call-me-turkey/overview)!

### Quick look

* *Name*: [Donâ€™t call me turkey!](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/dont-call-me-turkey/overview)
* *Skills*: Audio binary classification
* *Summary*: Build a model on a series of audio files to determine if they are made by a turkey or not.


> 
> In this competition you are tasked with finding the turkey sound signature from pre-extracted audio features. A simple binary problem, or is it? What does a turkey really sound like? How many sounds are similar? Will you be able to find the turkey or will you go a-fowl?
> 
> 
> 

### The Data

Check out the EDA section of [this notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/code/frtgnn/yam-potatoes-thanksgiving-2018) from [@frtgnn](https://www.kaggle.com/frtgnn) for a good exploratory data analysis. 

![graph showing target label counts](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F50767%2F77b98cced7e68d7a9a5759928514e143%2Fturkeygraph.png?generation=1667940588642610&alt=media)

## Creation

##### Creation Steps

1. Copy the competition
2. Make edits and launch

### Step 1: Copy the competition

![gif showing steps to clone the competition](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F50767%2F55753a5c322f955a65f90db62313c19a%2Fturkey2.gif?generation=1667946201531641&alt=media)

1. Go to the [competition overview](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/dont-call-me-turkey/overview)
2. Click the three dots in the upper right
3. Click â€œMake a Copyâ€
4. Chose a name
	1. Suggested: Audio Classification Competition - your class/group/event
5. Chose a url
	1. Suggested: audio-classification-competition-your-class-group-event
6. Select Limited
7. Click â€œContinueâ€

At this point you should have your own copy of the competition! Before you launch, however, you should make some edits.

### Step 2: Recommended Edits

* Overview Tab
	+ Timeline:
		- Update to your timeline
	+ Prizes:
		- Remove this page or update with class rules
* Host Tab
	+ Settings
		- Update the Brief Description
			* Mention your class/event
		- Update the Deadline
* Rules Tab
	+ Replace with the rules for your event
	+ Include things like rules on sharing and team mergers

At this point, heading over the Host tab, the â€œLaunch Checklistâ€ should say you are ready for launch! You can either schedule the launch for a specific time or launch right away. Participants will not be able to see or join the competition until it has launched.

### Helpful tips

1. This competition is â€œon your honorâ€ not to include the test data in your training. This would not be suitable for competitions where you need this information to be hidden.
2. Encourage participants to create and share their notebooks!
3. There are a ton of high quality notebooks on the [original competition](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/dont-call-me-turkey/code?competitionId=11880&sortBy=voteCount) you can quickly pull interesting models and create lessons around.
4. Encourage participants to help each other on the discussions forum!
5. There is a limited number of submissions per day, if you want to run a hackathon or event consider increasing it. This can be edited in the host -> settings tab.

If you get stuck please comment below - Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ve left out a step somewhere and your questions will help others. Happy Hosting!

2619158.content:
Evaluation metrics:\

Certainly! Here's a brief one-line description for each of the mentioned evaluation metrics:

Supervised Learning Metrics:

1. Classification Metrics:


	* Accuracy: Proportion of correctly classified instances.
	* Precision: Proportion of true positive predictions out of all positive predictions made.
	* Recall: Proportion of true positive predictions out of all actual positives.
	* F1 Score: Harmonic mean of precision and recall.
	* ROC AUC Score: Area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve.
	* Confusion Matrix: Matrix summarizing true positives, false positives, true negatives, and false negatives.
2. Regression Metrics:


	* MAE: Average of absolute differences between predictions and actual values.
	* MSE: Average of squared differences between predictions and actual values.
	* RMSE: Square root of MSE.
	* R2: Proportion of variance in dependent variable predictable from independent variables.
	* MSLE: Mean squared logarithmic error.
	* MAPE: Mean absolute percentage error.

Unsupervised Learning Metrics:

1. Clustering Metrics:
	* Silhouette Score: Measure of cohesion and separation of clusters.
	* Inertia: Sum of squared distances of samples to their closest cluster center.
	* Daviesâ€“Bouldin Index: Measure of cluster compactness.
	* Calinski-Harabasz Index: Measure of cluster separation.

Reinforcement Learning Metrics:

1. Policy Evaluation Metrics:


	* Average Return: Expected cumulative reward obtained from following a policy.
	* Value Function: Estimate of expected future return from a given state under a policy.
	* Advantage Function: Difference between the value of a state-action pair and the expected value of the state under the current policy.
2. Policy Improvement Metrics:


	* Policy Gradient: Gradient of expected return with respect to policy parameters.
	* Q-value: Expected return for taking an action from a given state and then following a particular policy.

Time Series Analysis Metrics:

1. Forecasting Metrics:


	* MAPE: Average percentage difference between predicted and actual values.
	* MASE: Scale-independent measure of forecast accuracy.
	* RMSE: Average magnitude of error in the same units as the target variable.
	* MFE: Average difference between predicted and actual values.
	* MAE: Average of absolute differences between predictions and actual values.
2. Anomaly Detection Metrics:


	* TPR/Recall: Proportion of true anomalies correctly identified.
	* Precision: Proportion of detected anomalies that are true anomalies.
	* F1 Score: Harmonic mean of precision and recall.
	* ROC Curve: Trade-off between TPR and FPR.

Natural Language Processing Metrics:

1. Language Generation Metrics:


	* BLEU Score: Measures quality of machine-translated text.
	* ROUGE Score: Measures overlap between system-generated and reference summaries.
	* METEOR Score: Measures quality of machine-translated text.
	* CIDEr Score: Measures diversity and relevance of generated captions.
2. Language Understanding Metrics:


	* Accuracy: Proportion of correctly classified instances.
	* Precision: Proportion of true positive predictions out of all positive predictions made.
	* Recall: Proportion of true positive predictions out of all actual positives.
	* F1 Score: Harmonic mean of precision and recall.

Computer Vision Metrics:

1. Object Detection Metrics:


	* IoU: Measure of overlap between predicted and ground truth bounding boxes.
	* AP: Measure of precision and recall for object detection models.
	* mAP: Average precision across multiple classes.
2. Image Classification Metrics:


	* Top-k Accuracy: Proportion of samples for which the correct label is among the top k predicted labels.
	* ROC AUC: Area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve.

Deep Learning-Specific Metrics:

1. Inception Score: Measures quality and diversity of generated images.
2. Frechet Inception Distance (FID): Measures distance between feature representations of real and generated images.

Market Basket Analysis Metrics (Apriori Algorithm):

1. Support: Proportion of transactions containing a particular itemset.
2. Confidence: Probability of seeing the consequent item in a transaction given that it contains the antecedent item.
3. Lift: Ratio of observed support to the support expected under independence

2345264.content:
Here are some common evaluation metrics used in machine learning:\

1.Accuracy: The ratio of correctly predicted instances to the total number of instances in the dataset. It is a simple and intuitive metric but may not be suitable for imbalanced datasets.\

2.Precision: The number of true positive predictions divided by the sum of true positive and false positive predictions. It measures the ability of the model to avoid false positives.\

3.Recall (Sensitivity): The number of true positive predictions divided by the sum of true positive and false negative predictions. It measures the ability of the model to identify positive instances.\

4.F1 Score: The harmonic mean of precision and recall. It provides a single metric that balances precision and recall.\

5.Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC-ROC): It measures the ability of a binary classification model to discriminate between positive and negative instances across different probability thresholds. A higher AUC-ROC indicates better model performance.\

6.Mean Squared Error (MSE): A commonly used metric for regression problems. It calculates the average of the squared differences between the predicted and actual values. Smaller MSE values indicate better performance.

363731.content:
Welcome to the first installment of ðŸ¤“Cloneable Competitions for the ClassroomðŸ¤“ where we feature one of our cloneable competitions. Even if you know nothing about Kaggle, using these simple steps you can get the competition up and running in 15 minutes. If you get stuck please comment below - Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ve left out a step somewhere and your questions will help others!

This time we are featuring a [Sales Forecasting Competition](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/tabular-playground-series-jan-2022) from our tabular playground series.

#### Quick look

* *Name*: [Tabular Playground Series - Jan 2022](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/tabular-playground-series-jan-2022)
* *Skills*: Intermediate Time Series / Forecasting on a Tabular Dataset
* *Summary*: Build sales forecasts to help the Kaggle team figure out whether KaggleMart or KaggleRama should become the official Kaggle merchandise store.


> 
> There are two (fictitious) independent store chains selling Kaggle merchandise that want to become the official outlet for all things Kaggle. We've decided to see if the Kaggle community could help us figure out which of the store chains would have the best sales going forward. So, we've collected some data and are asking you to build forecasting models to help us decide.
> 
> 
> Help us figure out whether KaggleMart or KaggleRama should become the official Kaggle outlet!
> 
> 
> 

#### The Data

Get a very good basic understanding of the data from this competition by reading through [@ambrosm](https://www.kaggle.com/ambrosm)â€™s exploratory data analysis notebook: [TPSJAN22-01 EDA which makes sense](https://www.kaggle.com/code/ambrosm/tpsjan22-01-eda-which-makes-sense)

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F50767%2F82c992a9ce3a50264209613f1ed49778%2Fhistogram.png?generation=1667429989934314&alt=media)

## Creation

Creation Steps

1. Copy the competition
2. Make edits and launch
3. Add helpful notebooks (optional)

#### Step 1: Copy the competition

1. Go to the [competition overview](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/tabular-playground-series-jan-2022)
2. Click the three dots in the upper right
3. Click â€œMake a Copyâ€
4. Chose a name
	1. Suggested: Sales Forecasting Competition - your class/group/event
5. Chose a url
	1. Suggested: Sales-forecasting-competition-your-class-group-event
6. Click â€œContinueâ€

![](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-forum-message-attachments/o/inbox%2F50767%2Fc9749ab7598c98063bbbc71bd4e77b95%2Fcreatgif.gif?generation=1667429878211612&alt=media)

At this point you should have a new competition. Before you launch, however, you should make some edits.

#### Step 2: Recommended Edits

* Overview Tab
	+ Description:
		- Remove â€œAbout Tabular Playground Seriesâ€
	+ Timeline:
		- Update to your timeline
	+ Prizes:
		- Remove this page or update with class rules
* Host Tab
	+ Settings
		- Update the Brief Description
			* Mention your class/event
		- Update the Deadline
		- Update access to â€œInvitation Onlyâ€ (unless running a public event)
	+ Images
		- Grab a nice image you have a license for, or use an image associated with your school or organization
* Rules Tab
	+ Replace with the rules for your event
	+ Include things like rules on sharing and team mergers

At this point, heading over the Host tab, the â€œLaunch Checklistâ€ should say you are ready for launch! You can either schedule the launch for a specific time or launch right away. Participants will not be able to see or join the competition until it has launched.

#### Step 3: Add helpful notebooks (optional)

Run this step AFTER launching your competition.

Looking at the original competition [Code tab sorting by most votes](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/tabular-playground-series-jan-2022/code?competitionId=33101&sortBy=voteCount) there are a couple really high quality notebooks you might want to consider adding to your competition. 

I would recommend â€œ[TPSJAN22-01 EDA which makes sense](https://www.kaggle.com/code/ambrosm/tpsjan22-01-eda-which-makes-sense)â€ by [@ambrosm](https://www.kaggle.com/ambrosm) as a great exploratory data analysis notebook to get your participants acquainted with the dataset. All public notebooks are released under the Apache 2.0 license so perfect to use in your class!

If you want any of these to show up:

1. click the â€œâ€¦â€ -> Copy and Edit
2. On the right hand side open the menu with the >| icon
3. Click Data -> â€œ+ Add Dataâ€
4. Click â€œCompetition Datasetsâ€ and search for your competition by name
5. Click the + button to add.
6. Navigate to your Code tab the notebook should be there!

### Helpful tips

1. If you donâ€™t want people outside your group to join the competition, make it â€œInvite onlyâ€ (see Host -> Settings)
2. Have students create and share their own notebooks!
	1. You might start off with an EDA (exploratory data analysis) notebook
	2. Assign different teams to attempt different model types and share the results in a notebook
3. Encourage engagement with the discussions tab
	1. Our kaggle competitions have a thriving community here and yours can too!
4. Encourage more frequent submissions rather than saving it all till the night before. There is a per day limit on submissions!
	1. This setting can be tweaked in the Host tab -> Settings pag
